sen.j: 加地子（かじし）は、日本の中世において、荘園領主・国衙（国司）へ納入する年貢・地子の他に、名主などの在地領主に対して納入した米（作得米）を指す租税の一形態。
sen.e: The term Kajishi means rice (sakutokumai) delivered as a tax to resident land-owner like myoshu (owner of rice fields) in the Japanese medieval period on top of nengu (customs)/jishi (land tax) for the lord of shoen(manor)/kokuga (provincial government officials) (kokushi (provincial governor)).

The term Kajishi means rice (sakutokumai) delivered as a tax to a resident land-owner like myoshu (owner of rice fields) in the Japanese medieval period on top of nengu (customs)/jishi (land tax) for the lord of shoen (manor)/kokuga (provincial government officials) (kokushi (provincial governor)).

The term Kajishi (加地子) means rice (sakutokumai) delivered as a tax to a resident land-owner like myoshu (owner of rice fields) in the Japanese medieval period on top of nengu (customs)/jishi (land tax) for the lord of shoen (manor)/kokuga (provincial government officials) (kokushi (provincial governor)).
sen.cmt: スペース削除(加地子)補足

sen.j: 本年貢・本地子の加徴分として賦課されたことから加地子と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: It was called Kajishi because it was imposed as a surcharge on honnengu/honjishi (normal nengu/jishi).
It was called Kajishi because it was imposed as a surcharge on honnengu/honjishi (normal nengu/jishi).
It was called Kajishi because it was imposed as a surcharge on honnengu/honjishi (normal nengu/jishi).

sen.j: 加持子（かじし）、加徳（かとく）、片子（かたこ）ともいう。
sen.e: It was also called Kajishi (加持子), katoku or Katako.
It was also called Kajishi (加持子), katoku or Katako.
It was also called Kajishi (加持子), katoku or Katako.

sen.j: 国衙領・荘園の名田化により、富豪百姓（田堵）が名主・荘官として現地経営にあたった。
sen.e: After kokugaryo (rice fields governed by provincial government office) and shoen became myoden (the land held by non-resident owners), wealthy farmers (Tato) were in charge of its management on the site as myoshu/shokan (officer governing shoen).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: After kokugaryo (rice fields governed by provincial government office) and shoen became myoden (land held by non-resident owners), wealthy farmers (Tato) were in charge of on site management as myoshu/shokan (officer governing shoen).

After kokugaryo (rice fields governed by provincial government office) and shoen became myoden (land held by non-resident owners), wealthy farmers (Tato) were in charge of on site management as myoshu/shokan (officer governing shoen).

sen.j: 名主・荘官は名田に係る官物・年貢を徴収して、国衙・荘園領主（領家）へ納入する義務を負っていた。
sen.e: Myoshu/shokan were obliged to collect kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes)/nengu imposed on myoden and deliver them to kokuga/lord of shoen (ryoke).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Myoshu/shokan were obliged to collect kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes)/nengu imposed on myoden and deliver them to kokuga/lord of shoen (ryoke).
Myoshu/shokan were obliged to collect kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes)/nengu imposed on myoden and deliver them to kokuga/lord of shoen (ryoke).

sen.j: これに伴って、名主・荘官にも加徴的な得分が認められるようになり、これが加地子と呼ばれるようになったのである。
sen.e: Under such arrangement, myoshu/shokan were also entitled to their own share, which was imposed on top of nengu/jishi, and this came to be called Kajishi.
Under such arrangement, myoshu/shokan were also entitled to their own share, which was imposed on top of nengu/jishi, and this was called Kajishi.
Under such arrangement, myoshu/shokan were also entitled to their own share, which was imposed on top of nengu/jishi, and this was called Kajishi.

sen.j: 加地子は、名主・荘官層の主要な収入源となり、本来の年貢・地子を上回ることも珍しくなく、年貢・地子の数倍に及ぶことすらあった。
sen.e: Kajishi was the principal source of income for myoshu/shokan and it was not uncommon to see the case where the amount of Kajishi exceeded that of normal nengu/jishi to the extent of several times.
Kajishi was the principal source of income for myoshu/shokan and it was not uncommon to see cases where the amount of Kajishi exceeded that of normal nengu/jishi by several times.
Kajishi was the principal source of income for myoshu/shokan and it was not uncommon to see cases where the amount of Kajishi exceeded that of normal nengu/jishi by several times.

sen.j: 最初、加地子は、耕作者から名主・荘官へ本年貢と合算して納入されていた。
sen.e: Originally, cultivators delivered the aggregate of Kajishi and honnengu to myoshu/shokan.
Originally, cultivators delivered the total Kajishi and honnengu to myoshu/shokan.
Originally, cultivators delivered the total Kajishi and honnengu to myoshu/shokan.

sen.j: その中から、名主・荘官が自らの得分である加地子を差し引いて、残分を年貢として国衙・領家へ納入していたのである。
sen.e: Myoshu/shokan deducted their share from it and delivered the balance to kokuga/ryoke.
Myoshu/shokan deducted their share and delivered the balance to kokuga/ryoke.
Myoshu/shokan deducted their share and delivered the balance to kokuga/ryoke.

sen.j: しかし、鎌倉時代ごろから、名主・荘官への加地子と、国衙・領家への本年貢が別個に納入されるようになっていった。
sen.e: However, Kajishi for myoshu/shokan and honnengu for kokuga/ryoke came to be delivered separately since the Kamakura Period.
However, Kajishi for myoshu/shokan and honnengu for kokuga/ryoke had been delivered separately since the Kamakura Period.
However, Kajishi for myoshu/shokan and honnengu for kokuga/ryoke had been delivered separately since the Kamakura period.

sen.j: このことは、耕作者である作人（さくにん）が直接の年貢負担者としての地位を獲得したこと、そして名主・荘官層が加地子を得るだけの地位に低下したことを意味する。
sen.e: The above indicates the fact that sakunin, a cultivator, obtained the status as a direct bearer of the burden of nengu while the status of myoshu/shokan declined to the one with which they only gained Kajishi.
The above indicates the fact that sakunin, cultivator, obtained the status as a direct bearer of the burden of nengu while the status of myoshu/shokan declined to the one only gaining Kajishi.
The above indicates the fact that sakunin, cultivator, obtained the status as a direct bearer of the burden of nengu while the status of myoshu/shokan declined to the one only gaining Kajishi.

sen.j: なお、加地子のみを得る名主を加地子名主職（かじしみょうしゅしき）という。
sen.e: In the meantime, myoshu who only gained Kajishi was called Kajishi myoshushiki.
In the meantime, myoshu, who only gained Kajishi, was called Kajishi myoshushiki.
In the meantime, myoshu, who only gained Kajishi, was called Kajishi myoshushiki.

sen.j: こうして、加地子を得る権利は分化していき、売買や寄進の対象となった。
sen.e: Over the time, the right to gain Kajishi was broken into small ones and became the object of sale or donation.
Over time, the right to gain Kajishi was divided and became the object of sale or donation.
Over time, the right to gain Kajishi was divided and became the object of sale or donation.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降の近世においては、小作料へと変質した。
sen.e: In the early- modern times, namely in the Edo Period, the nature of Kajishiki changed into kosakuryo (rent paid by tenant farmers).
In the early- modern times, namely during the Edo Period, the nature of Kajishiki changed into kosakuryo (rent paid by tenant farmers).
In the early-modern times, namely during the Edo period, the nature of Kajishi changed into kosakuryo (rent paid by tenant farmers).
